newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden's Riksbank sees limited room for repo cuts.
newsitem.headline: Sweden's Riksbank sees limited room for repo cuts.

text.p: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, said on Thursday that there was still some limited room to lower its key repo rate.
"In the light of the available information, the Riksbank considers that there is still some limited room for lowering the repo rate," said Riksbank governor Urban Backstrom.
However the analysis of incoming economic data could lead the Riksbank to revise this view, Backstrom said.
"The conclusion to be drawn from the assessments that are made may also turn out to be an unchanged repo rate," he told a news conference.

The Riksbank earlier announced a cut in all three interest rates in its three-tiered rate management system, cutting the lending and deposit rates by 0.50 percentage points and the repo by an unexpected 25 basis points to 4.60 percent.

"Since the summer and autumn, there have been more substantial signs of improved activity in industry as well as in trade. The conditions for economic growth in Sweden in the next two years therefore appear to be good," Backstrom added.
"Even so, it seems that inflationary pressure will be moderate," he said, adding the prospects of inflation being in line with the bank's inflation target remain good.
